fdd:description.p: MOOF is a Macintosh floppy disk image format designed for use with Applesauce, the Macintosh floppy drive controller. Applesauce was developed for retro-computing enthusiasts and digital archivists who need to work with floppy disks. The MOOF format is able to preserve copy-protected disk images by emulating protected software. According to John Morris' MOOF Disk Image Reference 1.0, it is one of the most simple image formats and it accurately emulates the Integrated Woz Machine (IWM) or Sander-Wozniak Integrated Machine (SWIM) chip. MOOF also encodes metadata about the disk image, such as disk name, product name, publisher, system requirements, and language. These are stored in the optional META Chunk as key-value pairs. Multiple values are pipe-separated.
The name MOOF is not an acronym. It is a reference to Dogcow, a part of Mactintosh lore.

fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:shortDescription: MOOF, a Macintosh floppy disk image format designed for Applesauce, caters to retro-computing enthusiasts and digital archivists MOOF encodes essential metadata, including disk details, product information, publisher, system requirements, and language.

fdd:relationship.fdd:comment: WOZ format. A format for the Apple II disk image. Both WOZ and MOOF are offshoots of the Applesauce emulation project. The MOOF and WOZ formats encode different metadata. Not described separately on this resource.
A2R format. Also an offshoot of the Applesauce project. A container format for raw disk image files. Not described separately on this resource.

fdd:localUse.fdd:preference: The Library of Congress has not yet expressed any format preference for disk image files.

fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:disclosure: Version 1.0 is fully documented and disclosed. Comments welcome.
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:documentation: Documented in MOOF Disk Image Reference 1.0.

fdd:adoption.p: Support for MOOF was added to the MAME Project on September 28, 2022 in release 0.248.
Support for MOOF was added to the Big Mess o’ Wires (BMOW) emulation firmware in December 2022.

fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:licensingAndPatents: Created by John K. Morris. No license. Comments welcome.
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:transparency: Dependent upon algorithms and tools to read.

fdd:selfDocumentation.p: According to MOOF Disk Image Reference 1.0, the format utilizes a chunk-based, binary format designed for future-proof expandability. All data is stored in little-endian. Technical and descriptive metadata are stored in the INFO chunk. The chunk is versioned to allow for adding additional metadata in the future.

fdd:magicNumbers.fdd:note: All data is stored in Little Endian. The header is 12 bytes. The first 8 bytes contain the file signature. Following the magic number string of “MOOF” is (hex)FF, an intentionally blank space. This blank space exists to ensure there is no data corruption and that the magic numbers values are valid. However this practice is not required. The last 4 bytes of the header contain a CRC32 checksum of all remaining data in the file. See the specification for more details.

fdd:values.fdd:note: PRONOM has no corresponding entry as of January 2024.

fdd:notes.fdd:history: The format takes its name from the spotted dog iconography crafted by Susan Kare, an early Macintosh designer. As a tribute to the creativity and playful ethos of the Macintosh pioneers, this disk image format is aptly named MOOF.

fdd:urlReference.tag: MOOF support on Big Mess o’ Wires.

fdd:urlReference.comment: A collection of .MOOF floppy disk images from the early Macintosh era.

fdd:urlReference.tag: "The Dogcow". Mark "The Red" Harlan. April 1989. Accessed via the Internet Archive.
